abstract: Poor population in America’s suburbs--long a symbol of a stable and prosperous American middle class--rose by 53 percent between 2000 and 2010, forcing suburban communities nationwide to re-evaluate their identities and how they serve their populations; as a result, suburban municipalities once concerned with police, fire and roads are confronting a new set of issues, namely how to help poor residents without the array of social programs that cities have, and how to get those residents to services without public transportation.
snippet: The poor population in America’s suburbs rose 53 percent last decade, double the 26 percent increase in cities, confronting communities with unaccustomed challenges.
lead_paragraph: The poor population in America’s suburbs rose 53 percent last decade, double the 26 percent increase in cities, confronting communities with unaccustomed challenges.

headline.main: Outside Cleveland, Snapshots of Poverty’s Surge in the Suburbs
headline.print_headline: Outside Cleveland, Snapshots of Poverty’s Surge in the Suburbs
headline.seo: A 53% Surge in Poverty Rate Is Reshaping Suburbs
